newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian Socialists withdraw backing for cabinet.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian Socialists withdraw backing for cabinet.

text.p: Bulgaria's former ruling Socialists have withdrawn their support from the interim cabinet, complaining of a lack of transparency over a new IMF accord and politically-motivated sackings of state employees.

In an open letter to President Petar Stoyanov published by Bulgarian newspapers on Monday, Bulgarian Socialist Party (BSP) leader Georgi Parvanov said an all-party agreement which ended a month of street protests led by the Union of Democratic Forces (UDF) was not being respected.
"The UDF betrayed the principles agreed to lead the country out of crisis. The caretaker cabinet and yourself openly ignored those principles in your activity," Parvanov said.

The Socialists agreed on February 4 to abandon attempts to form a new government. Stoyanov appointed a caretaker cabinet, which contains many UDF members, to rule until elections on April 19 and to negotiate with the IMF.
"At this stage the BSP still has not received the text of the accord between the interim government and the IMF," Parvanov said.
He said details of the accord, which will include a tough fixed exchange rate regime, were unclear, and Bulgarians did not realise the high social cost of the reforms.

Countries of the G-24 industrialised nations meet in Brussels on Tuesday and Wednesday to discuss additional support for Bulgaria, and the IMF board is expected to approve the standby accord on Friday.
He said sackings of directors of companies and government departments had been politically motivated.

"We are worried by the fact that in some spheres, especially in the tourist business, we have new faces connected to strong-arm (criminal) groups, which is maybe an attempt to reward their efforts in the January unrest," Parvanov said.
Parvanov met Stoyanov last month to express his concern, and Stoyanov said that in his view the reforms by the new cabinet did not go far enough.
